text: I'm Jim Keller senior vice president of
sales for North Bay North Bay provides
big data analytics and self-service
business intelligence solutions for
education companies and the ecosystem
they live in we focus on helping
publishers higher education institutions
courseware providers and EdTech
companies formulate and devise their Big
Data strategies will that be a data Lake
enterprise data platform running on
redshift or perhaps even a migration
from an on-premises data warehouse to
AWS in the cloud so North Bay given our
history in the education marketplace has
really formed a series of what we call
packaged services that uniquely address
the education sector so organizations in
the education marketplace face some
fairly unique challenges budgetary
constraints pace of innovation
instantiated systems whether it be for
sis or learning management or other
systems so really they warrant and
deserve and need a set of specific
services that are geared for them and
North Bay has launched a series of we
call packaged services which are really
fixed budget fixed time frame services
that allow those organizations to try
out a scenario whether it's a data lake
or a warehouse or something like that
take a use case implement it fully have
end users interact with that through AWS
on the cloud and then once proven
through that process then then proceed
with a full-on implementation so when we
started with scholastic most of their
enterprise was running on an IBM as/400
for decades they had over 5,000
workloads running on that IBM as/400
that coupled with sequel server
instances of over 300 so imagine the
magnitude of that environment and trying
to move
business from on-premises to the cloud
so many of our customers have asked us
to explore machine learning and
predictive analytics as an extension of
their AWS data Lake or data warehouse so
when you think about for instance
courseware providers and think about
interaction between a student and a
digital book and think about iterations
of those engagements that users have so
how many times do they restart a page or
how many times do they restart a chapter
and then building a learning model so
that teachers and administrators and
even courseware providers would start
better understanding how students and
certain student profiles may start
interacting with that courseware before
they even start and therefore adjust
those that courseware to be more
effective from day one so the education
competency I think is really important
both for partners such as North Bay but
most importantly AWS customers living
and working in the edu ecosystem so
imagine an education customer trying to
find an expert provider of services that
specializes in AWS and in our case big
data analytics and business intelligence
solutions and trying to select those
partners from a myriad of sources so
what the edu competency does is really
provides those customers with a filter
they know that someone like North Bay is
vetted proven both technically and from
a business standpoint so that when they
do reach out they know that they're
getting the cream of the crop
